title: Ticket #1821: Add support for EC2 REST interface to grid universe
description:
Condor speaks the EC2 SOAP interface under the grid universe type 'amazon'. A lot of cloud services speak the EC2 REST interface, but not the SOAP interface. Thus, Condor cannot submit jobs to them. Adding EC2 REST support to Condor should be pretty simple, reusing the SOAP-based code where-ever possible.

Much of the existing amazon_gahp should be reusable. We would rip out the gsoap layer and replace it with something that talks simple HTTP. That could be gsoap's http layer or libcurl or something else, as deemed appropriate. If we want to replace the SOAP support for REST support, no other parts of Condor would have to change. If we want to continue handling SOAP requests, some changes would be required in condor_submit and condor_gridmanager.

References

  • http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/ Describes all the commands and their attributes, with examples.
  • http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/DeveloperGuide/ Section Making API Request > Making Query Requests describes how to speak the REST interface.
remarks:
2010-Dec-22 12:23:34 by matt:
Are there services with an EC2 facade that you have in mind other than Eucalyptus?

+1 to libcurl or the like

You'll have to change condor_submit for sure if you go to the REST API, because the credentials needed are different.

2010-Dec-22 12:33:57 by jfrey:
Condor_submit doesn't look in the files. We could use the same attribute names but tell users to use the other credentials. That can be confusing, though. I'm really tempted to introduce a new grid-type of 'ec2' and deprecate 'amazon'.

2011-Jan-11 14:35:09 by tlmiller:
Current status: All AMAZON_VM_* GAHP commands (START, STOP, STATUS, STATUS_ALL, RUNNING_KEYPAIR, CREATE_KEYPAIR, DESTROY_KEYPAIR, and KEYPAIR_NAMES) have been implemented using the Query API. These commands have been tested against Amazon's EC2, at the level of the GAHP's stdio interface.

Build changes: I added one library (cURL) to those required (although I haven't removed the now-superflous gSOAP or Kerberos). I used PCRE (which could be coded around), expat, and OpenSSL, but these did not require new linking. I made additional use of standard Condor libraries/functions (condor_base64.h and Regex.h). I have not eliminated gsoap_commands.cpp, although it's unused by the Query API. (Trying to avoid mucking about too much with cmake.)

Code changes: I eliminated the contents of gsoap_commands.cpp, since I wouldn't be using it, and didn't want to keep updating it to match the amazonCommands.h header, to which I made moderate changes. The layout is broadly similar, although I implement the core of the Query API functionality in AmazonRequest::SendRequest(), as opposed to handing the job off to another source file. The key implication here is that I used a common std::map< std::string, std::string > in AmazonRequest instead of explicit variables in the subclasses for the different parameters. While this is obviously less efficient (although the Query API does require that parameters be sorted by name), it allows AmazonRequest::SendRequest() to be completely generic in a natural and simple way. I made a small tweak to the class heirarchy, as well (AmazonVMStatus now inherits from AmazonVMStatusAll). I replaced the StringList in AmazonStatusResult with a std::vector< std::string > > because StringList had some problem with its assignment function.

amazonCommands.cpp has been (almost; I haven't purged the #include list) totally replaced by the Query API implementation. I erred on the side of simplicity in the implementation; it undoubtedly makes too many copies of various bits and pieces. However, I'm reasonably confident that it doesn't leak memory.

TODO: It remains to conduct the Condor-level tests (which should go smoothly, as I have made no GAHP-level changes) and finish tweaking the error-reporting -- I think everything of interest is detected, I just don't know if it's going to the right place.

After talking with ToddT, it sounds like this code will be integrated into Condor as its own GAHP. Code review will occur with Jaime when he returns.

2011-Jan-13 16:18:29 by tlmiller:
Condor-level testing revealed a bug, but that has been fixed and the new gahp verified against both EC2 and the Magellan (Eucalyptus) clouds.

2011-Jan-24 20:46:43 by bbockelm:
If possible, it would be really nice if you could test the OpenStack interfaces. As Eucalyptus appears to have scalability issues, some of the "big sites" appear to be headed to OpenStack which theoretically support the EC2 REST interface.

2011-Mar-28 13:51:03 by tlmiller:
The test failures which have been causing me so much trouble appear to be caused by a bug elsewhere in the test suite; x86_64_rhap_5.3 does not properly transfer the ec2_sim (amazon GAHP) or queryAPI-sim (ec2 GAHP) binaries to the tests, but x86_64_rhap_5 does. I'm not sure why being one of the official ports matters, but it would explain why Tim St. Clair and I were getting different testing results.

2011-Apr-01 14:10:41 by tlmiller:
Pushed to master for 7.7.0. Documentation remains.

2011-Apr-01 14:11:44 by tlmiller:
(In particular, don't forget to explain that the secret and public key attributes are filenames, not literals.)

2011-Apr-04 09:57:58 by tiradani:
I compiled and tested the V7_5-ec2_gahp-publicbranch branch in the Condor git repository against OpenStack at Argonne. Condor was able to manage the VMs correctly. The only caveat is that if you want a public IP address, you have to manually allocate and associate one to the VM.

2011-Apr-04 10:40:14 by tstclair:
there is support for elastic_ip's using the rest interface.

the submission parameter is: ec2_elastic_ip = "your.public.ip.address" <- alloc'd through their interface.

2011-Apr-13 15:07:51 by tlmiller:
Documented in the 7.7 manual, including the release notes.
